ParentCompanyName: Ag-Chem, Inc. d/b/a UAP Northeast - Girdletree, MD

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
For further information please contact Mike Rew (410-632-1371), the UAP Northeast employee responsible for supervising the operation of this facility. Bill Sirman (410-632-2398) operates the plant during the use season.
I. Facility Policy
The owner, management and employees of UAP Northeast - Girdletree, MD are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release occurs, management is prepared to work with the local fire department, LEPC, or other authorities to mitigate any release, and to minimize the impact of the release on people and the environment.
II. Facility Information
The only activity at this facility on Queponco Road - Newark, MD is the storage and dispensing, and sale of anhydrous ammonia to local farmers as a nitrogen fertilizer nutrient.
The maximum quantity stored in the 30,000 gallon tank is 132,000 pounds. (85% of storage tank size)
Farmer customers bring their 1,000 gallon nurse tanks to the facility to be filled and then take them immediately back to their farm.
III. Scenario for the "Worst Case Release"
The worst case release would be release of the total contents of the 30,000 gal. Tank over a 10 minute period. This maximum quantity would be the volume of the tank at 85% capacity as limited by design standards. The distance to the toxic endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 2.43 miles.
IV. Scenario for the "Alternative Release"
An alternative release scenario is based on a release from a broken 2 inch transfer hose. It is assumed that the release is manually shut off at 2 minutes duration. In this case the distance to the toxic endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 ppm) is 1.14 miles.
V. Accidental Release and Prevention Program
The facility operates under accepted anhydrous ammonia industry standards for storage and handling.
VI. Five Year Accident History
This facility was put into service in April 2001 and has no history of any accidents.
VII. Emergency Response Plan
In the case of an u

ncontrolled release, location personnel would notify authorities and evacuate.
Facility has provided Emergency Planning and Right to Know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). UAP Northeast is working with local authorities to be included in the community Emergency Response Plan.
VIII. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Safety improvement is an ongoing process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions and evaluate employee training. UAP Northeast is planning to install perimeter fencing in the near future.
